A fast-paced, physics-based game where you try to play soccer with a decked out rocket car while navigating a field of 14 year old drivers and grown men pretending to be 14. Games last ~5 minutes, making it great for both casual and competitive gamers. Being both amazing and addictive, I highly recommend it.  Edited after extensive amounts of competitive gameplay ranging from All-Star to Challenger Elite solo 3s que so solo players can have an idea of what to expect.  Prospect rankings: -Players have little or no knowledge of field spacing. More often than not, the entire team will clump on the ball.   -Players exercise little to no field awareness. Plan on teammates bumping you off the ball or hitting the ball just to hit it, rather than letting a teammate with a better angle clear or progress the ball  -Whiffing. It's a whiff fest. Don't plan on players always making connection with the ball.  -Rare aerials. Most game play will be on the ground  -Tip off roles. Players will most likely all rush the ball on tip off  -Empty goals. Players will rarely play goalie or rotate field position. Most often when there is a goalie, it's a dedicated player who is passive more often than not. Many trash goals and long range goals happen, as you can shoot from almost anywhere on the field with 3 playing forward.  -Players only play the ball, directly to the goal the majority of the time with minimal usage of the corners/walls. You really don't have to worry about players blocking angles with their car or demolishing other cars idling on the field. You really don't have to worry about too many players at this level anticipating the angles of the ball, whether it's leaving a car or a wall.  -Players are generally uncomfortable playing backwards and change direction awkwardly.  -Spatial skills. You don't really have to worry about people using the ball cam and exercising solid mental mapping of ball and player positions.  Challenger Rankings: -Hit or miss on player spacing up until Division 4+. Players often clump to the ball and leave gaps in the field.  -Players exercise *some* field awareness up until Division 4. Teammates will often bump other teammates off the ball or hit the ball just to hit it, rather than let the teammate with the better angle take the touch. Players will most likely have an understanding of position/role rotation at this point.  -Whiffing. Doesn't happen nearly as much once you're in Challenger division, and more often than not it results in an opportunity for a goal.  -Aerials. Expect players to fly.  -Tip off roles. Players generally know their role at tip off. Forward/side challenges on tip off, one plays mid for the second touch, one generally plays goal. It's hit or miss on if the goalie goes to the corner to grab the full boost, often resulting in trash tip off goals. It's been my experience that the stronger goalies collect the boosts within the goal box.  -Empty goals. Players still tend to over extend from time to time, leaving empty goals. Furthest one back should hover half field and look for cleanups on centers or to play the ball forward when it is pushed towards them. Count on there being a goalie or someone near goal, however. You will find that many of the goalies do not challenge tackles, the success of a passive goalie isn't consistent. Players are more creative with shooting at this level.  -Players no longer only play the ball. Plan on being demolished for idling under a ball while it falls to the ground or while playing a passive goalie. Plan on players anticipating the angle of the ball leaving a wall or car. They no longer play directly to the goal, especially if the box is loaded. Anticipate high balls off the wall for centers, as well as players playing on the walls and flipping it to mid/goal with a well timed jump.  -Players are comfortable playing both backwards and forwards. Spin someone out? Plan on them seamlessly transitioning to reverse/forward. Demolishing them completely is your best bet.  -Spatial skills. It's been my experience that good players use the ball cam. Plan on them having a solid mental map of ball position, car positions, and field position.   -Speed boosts. Players will now be strategically pathing through boosts. Rarely will they strategically steal the other team's boosts in front of the goal while applying pressure on the goal.  Challenger Elite+  -Expect anything. From players demolishing idle cars to strategically removing boosts from the field, it's gonna happen. Passive goalies are generally a thing of the past here. Expect any lead touches to be challenged.  -Players understand position, roles, and are skilled when it comes to spatial skills and anticipation.   -Whiffing *rarely* happens and most likely results in a shot on goal. Anticipate connection on every challenge.  -Control. Once at this level, players have an initimate understanding of how to use their car. Plan for them to play the most advantageous angle when it comes to near/far post on shooting. Crossing/center can happen from almost anywhere, whether it be from a high spot on the wall or from a defending goalie box.  While this isn't everything, I hope it gives players an idea of what to expect.   This is a great game!

All in all, great dynamic game with a big learning curve, what I mean by this is that it takes actuall skilll, and not the press of a shoot key, you can do endless things with the ball, but it's all up to you!  From aerials to dribbles, practice makes perfect, and to play this game, you need to commit to it, as this incredibly dynamic game, requires precision, and carefull analasis of the situation. Saying that, getting started is easy, and especially if you do all the trainings daily, as part of a routine.  The look of cars in the game is hugely expandable, from making the flash, to a fancy taxi, the possabilities are endless, and the DLC's are worth while, as they add a whole new look upon the game, with new decals, paint jobs, wheels and boosts, your possibilites will be hugely expandable. I also love the fact that you do not have to pay, to get a beautiful car, the default cars, paint jobs and boosts etc. are very good, as well as the new robust trade up system, get very rare items within the matter of hours of effort.  The one DOWNSIDE of the game, are season restarts, as they cause alot of good players to drop into very low ranks, and ruin the experiance, however a few weeks after the Neo Tokyo update, which also restarted the ranking system in matchmaking, everything was back to normal.  - WH0

At the time of writing this, I've only played the game for four hours, but it's a nice contrast from my usual blood, gore, and horror games. The playing field seems to be solely separated by how well a person can navigate their vehicle; all vehicles have the same capabilities, it's your responsibility to learn the controls, tolerances, and mechanics. Vehicles don't level up and become faster or more agile to give the player an advantage, only the player can improve themselves by learning the mechanics and the physics.  The mechanics are fairly simple and there is a tutorial and a free-roam area for you to get accustomed to how the game works and controls. When you're ready to play online, you can choose the level of people you wish to play with or you can customize a search to match you with available games. Player levels are based solely on how many points a player has scored by making goals, defending, or performing a number of other actions.  I really like that games are fairly quick (there's a timer) and I can typically just jump in for a couple games, have some fun, and then drop it. There's no commitment to leveling stuff to gain advantages, it's just good, quick fun.  I'm running the game on an i7-940 with a GTX 970 and I'm running the game at 120Hz (check PC Gaming Wiki to unlock framerate) and I've not had any issues; I'm also using a 360 gamepad and it has worked great for this.

One of my new favorite competitive games. I went into this game with no expectations thinking I wasn't going to like it all that much.  I was wrong.  It's soccer with cars. There's not a whole lot to go over in a review. It might sound like a silly concept on the surface but a great physics engine, tight controls, and smooth gameplay elevate a simple idea to something really special. When you get your hands on it you can immediately feel just how well it plays. It's easy for anybody to pick up and play and yet challenging to master.   Besides the game itself, the only other real feature is that you can customize your car from a good selection of different bodies, accessories, paints, and patterns. There's quite a lot of variety so it's pretty easy to make your car stand out with all the different combinations at your disposal.  Only thing I think this game is missing is a replay history ala Halo. You *can* save replays, but if you accidentally forget to press the button in the post-game lobby there's no way to get it again. A constant history of 5-10 games that you could look back at and save the replays of would be a welcome feature.

Great Game. Definitely Reccomend. A new twist on soccer (I'm american) that's surprisingly fun  Pros-------  - Lots of customization - Great gameplay - Online multiplayer which rarely has lag - Server host locations for a wide variety of regions - Cross platform gameplay between PC and PS4 - No car is game breaking. They all perform the same. So the DLC cars are not pay to win, just more decoration options. - Don't need a controller to play, keyboard controls are great, I suggest remapping a few though - Nice selection of team sizes ranging from 1 vs 1 - 4 vs 4 - Ranked gameplay for all you competitive players out there  Cons------  - Can't make cross-platform parties - 4 vs 4 can get laggy  I personally love the game and may be a tad biased in favor of it. It's a game you can put hundreds, if not thousands of hours into and not get bored of. I suggest playing with friends as it can make your experience more enjoyable.  tl;dr I reccomend buying and the DLC has some pretty nice looking stuff for the price, so get that too if you like the game as much as me and have a bit of extra money.

This has been one of the biggest if not THE biggest surprises of the year for me. The moment I played it I was hooked. This is a very well balanced casual and competitive game with a towering skill ceiling. It has been a real joy to see my skill improve from day one to now over one hundred hours of gameplay. There are a variety of cars to choose from which all behave the same for the most part (there are slight differences in the hitboxes and turn radii afaik) and you can also customize these cars with paint schemes, skins, hats, wheels, and antennas (these do not change car performance). You can choose to play 1v1 up to 4v4 either casually or competitively with a rankings ladder and all of the maps look great but have the same layout (devs have mentioned adding more unusual layouts in the future). I was on the fence about this game for a month or so after release but I am kicking myself for not picking this up earlier. I have played 104 hours and the game hasn't become stale. Rocket League is pure, unadulterated fun.   P.S. As of this writing, there are 3 DLC packs available at reasonable prices that add nothing but new vehicles and cosmetic options.

I dont write reviews often but this game very much warrants one.   Rocket League is such an amazingly fun game to play. Its so ridiculously simple in gameplay, but that's the very thing that makes it so great.   There is something over 150 customization options for the 10(?) currently available cars, with surely more to come in the future.   There arent a vast amount of maps available right now, but there is talk of much free DLC coming in the future including new Stadiums to play in which is amazing to hear.  This is a game that benefits highly from playing with friends, because so far every game Ive played with other people has been some of the best fun Ive had in a multiplayer game in a long time. If you aren't planning on playing with friends the majority of the time, you might find the game gets a little repetetive and stale. However it makes for a great party game as it comes available with up to 4 player split screen.  The only cons I can give at this time (July 18th, 2015) are that it has had a few server issues the past week or so, but that is primarily due to the large increase in players due to its popularity, this shouldnt be a problem for much longer, if it even is anymore. The last thing I can think of is that the game has a weird habit of Crashing randomly during different times in gameplay. The last few times its happened prior to the startup of a round, and to all of the people in my party at the same time, so it hasnt impacted any games in progress so far.  At a $20 price tag this game is more than worth it, I probably wouldn't have been upset with a higher price tag either after playing this game, its just that fun. I can highly reccomend this to anyone who thinks that this game looks fun, but might not be worth the price.

Release after release, I wait for a good game to be released. One that is fun, has lots of replayabillity, and has no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t day one dlc. Well, that game has come.  When I first saw this game, I didn't think much of it. I just thought the screenshots looked meh, and thought the idea was cheesy. Boy was I wrong. I was blown away at how good this game was. The idea is simple and easy to learn, but hard to master. The gameplay is nonstop fun, and puts you on edge every time that ball gets to your side of the arena.  The game game balance is great because NO ONE IS OP. There are different car types, but they don't really affect gameplay. The customization is great AND FREE! I can not tell you how happy I was to see that the game developers thought about their community and didn't make users pay extra for something dumb like customization.  The only part that I don't like about this game is it's ranked mode. There is a 1v1, 2v2, and 3v3. The only problem is that you can't invite friends to play in a 3v3. It is strictly soloque. This really needs to change. I can't tell you how many times my two friends and I want to play ranked, but can't because of this.  I love this game and will be playing it for a long time. Final score: 8.7/10

Excelling in sport means knowing when a moment is outside of your control and recognizing when an opportunity is there to seize. In Rocket League, both events occur countless times in any given match--not surprising for a game heavily inspired by soccer. It caters to the competitive realist who thrills in having sole control of the ball for a few seconds despite knowing it can be snatched at any time. The best part is that you get to kill opponents' dreams and agonize in your own losses from the comfort of a very, very fast car.  Every moment in Rocket League demands split-second judgment. Are you the assertive type who takes control of the immediate situation at the risk of being in the middle of a chaotic, unpredictable scrum? Are you more of a long-term planner, one who watches your cohorts fight over a ball in a corner with the confidence that the ball will inevitably escape. When this happens, are you ready at the top of the penalty arc with the hope that the loose ball will roll between you and the goal? This echoes Wayne Gretzky's words of wisdom: 'A good hockey player plays where the puck is. A great hockey player plays where the puck is going to be.' Rocket League offers countless opportunities to be Gretzky--or Nostradamus.Rocket League thrives on speed and momentum. This is best exemplified by the gravity-defying excitement of driving up the side of any of the game's arenas. This ability is useful as well as thrilling. Without the curves along the edges of the pitch, cars would simply bang into the wall. Constantly having to reverse and make three-point turns over a five-minute match would be a disappointing series of momentum-ending buzzkills. Rocket League has none of these obstacles. The curved corners means you do not lose momentum. Your tires will smoothly caress these bends as you ride the walls horizontally, chasing the ball in parallel with rest of the cars on the pitch. Given that the ceiling is also fair game, every player will feel compelled to attempt a gravity-defying loop across the width of the roof. The game's physics and your limited boost will prevent you from completing such a stunt, but you'll attempt it anyway.The ball in play is comparable to that perpetually bouncing beach ball you find at every music festival, only slightly less buoyant. It bounces and flies in unpredictable directions when touched by two parties at the same time. This is where fortune favors the Rocket League sportsperson who embraces chaos. Transcendence comes when you realize you don't have to be in control of the ball at all times; you should chase it only when you think you can make a difference.A goal scored ends the fleeting, yet fulfilled, existence of a ball. In its death, the ball's life is celebrated with a literal bang. It's a colorful, smoke-filled explosion that sends all the cars flying away at heights and velocities that would kill any human in real life. It is so spectacular that you can't help but savor the blast, even if you weren't on the team that scored. Rocket League is that rare kind of video-game sport where you're compelled to play your best, even when you're being blown out 5-1 and there's only a minute left on the clock.  There's no shortage of advanced ball handling in online multiplayer. In Rocket League, experience leads to tactical thinking. Tactical thinking leads to performing with finesse. You cannot open car doors to use them like arms; that would be the equivalent of a handball in soccer. Instead, you can spin your car forwards, backwards, and sideways, which is analogous to bicycle kicks and headers. Once you learn to use these moves to advance the ball, you are soon ricocheting shots on goal. Over time, you also discover that your chances of scoring are boosted by hitting the car closest to the ball rather than the ball itself. It's all obvious highlight reel material, which is why the replay save option is so welcome. Learning and mastering these advanced moves makes playing Rocket League endlessly absorbing, even after you've logged over 50 matches.Playing a single-player season in rookie mode is as useful a practice ground as the training mode itself. Without real-life competitors ruthlessly charging to the center of the field for the drop ball, you can practice making spectacular goals from midfield. The drawback is that imperfect A.I. applies to both teams, meaning that your computer-controlled squadmates will average at least one incompetent move per match, whether it's taking the ball to the far side of your end of the field or blocking your path to the ball.  Rocket League's replay value lies in the draw of constant participation, not in a progressive system of unlockable advanced abilities or shoehorned novelty modes. All the arenas are uniform and consistent in shape, without any bells and whistles like the terraces in its predecessor, Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket-Powered Battle-Cars. The only variables are the team sizes, A.I. difficulty, and season lengths. This lack of flexibility adds legitimacy to the sport, mirroring the steadfast traditions within many professional sports, some of which are over a hundred years old.  The only thing better than a car with a Viking helmet and bubble exhausts are detailed blades of grass. The only thing better than a car with a Viking helmet and bubble exhausts are detailed blades of grass. This thoughtfulness extends to the studio's crafting of a convincing world where Rocket League is the number one sport. You see it in the multi-tier, sold-out arenas and you hear it from the indistinct chants of allegiance from the fans. The crowd goes 'Oooohhhh!' or 'Aaaaahh!', whether it's a goal or a key ball hit at midfield. These sprinkles of realism aren't strictly necessary but are greatly appreciated; for instance, the pitch itself features blades of grass that all move independently. These manicured fields are best admired during the pre-match camera shots, but you can't be faulted for staring at them in the middle of a game. They are complemented by the myriad customization parts, from wildly swinging antenna flags to neon-blue engine exhaust trails.  The joy of Rocket League rests on the countless plans that are conceived and discarded every other second in any given match. Trying to predict where and how the ball will bounce next is a game within the game. Despite the use of cars, Rocket League emulates the emotional surges typical of The Beautiful Game, such as the rush of an unexpected fast break or a well-timed header into a goal. With Rocket League, the promising concept of combining two wonderful things--cars and soccer--is equally magnificent in execution. You can't say the same thing about, say, combining cake and fruit to make fruitcake, as the comedian Jim Gaffigan observed.

This game is an homage to the philosophy of gaming. I say that because it succeeds at its one and only goal: to be pure, unadulterated fun.  The controls are incredibly simple to understand, yet there are sophisticated techniques that even the most grizzled veterans will have trouble executing to perfection. Teamwork is requisite for success, and when paired against an equally skilled team you'll be hard-pressed to find another game that is more satisfyingly competitive. There is a level of intensity that this game will bring to you and your friends that most other games simply cannot compete with. Best of all, the price of admission is a measly $20; 1/3 of what I'd be willing to pay for a game of this caliber.  Furthermore, the technical details of the game are just as pristine as the gameplay. The menus flow gracefully and the multiplayer is admirably consistent. You'll be out of a match and into a new one before you have time to get a glass of water.  There was an idea that was Rocket League, and this idea was executed to perfection. Not once have I longed for something more than that blissful experience this game provides. If you're opening your wallet for a game any time soon, make it this one. You will not be let down.

Fun and addicting game, it's more than just kicking the ball with your car.  Once you get the game you'll truly understand what I mean. I recommend you watch Team Rocket videos on YouTube, the videos help alot if you're starting new.(Type in 'Rocket League Team Rocket Tutorials')  Also keep in mind, you won't be flying around and free style aerial shooting on goals in a single day, it does take time.  Train whenever you can. Even when you're searching for a match, take advantage and warm up in the training.  The best way to play as a beginner is with a party, so if you have friends who play this game, play with them.   I do recommend a controller for this game, I personally use the Xbox360 afterglow controller, seems to be running very well.  Another thing to add, change the controller key binds and camera settings to what makes you most comfortable.  It's possible to play splitscreen too, if you have 2(or more) wired controllers, you can plug them in and enjoy splitscreen with your friends.  As for the DLC, if you want to get one, i recommend the Supersonic Fury DLC. It has the best cars and they are mostly used by pros.

*nominated this game for the 'i thought this game was cool before it won an award' award*   OK, first off i want to state that this game is stupidly fun to play with. This game is fun because once you pull off one of those backwards-turtle-reverse-aerial shots, you feel amazingly satisfied. If i had a say in improvements in this game, i would say that you could improve visibility as my friends could not tell where i was due to environments' background colour such as the underwater submarine level as the goals are almost/the same as my car's colour. Rocket League just scratches that itch, y'know? It hits that point of bite-sized gameplay that's not too long to get boring but long enough to feel satisfying. Then it takes that bite-size, polishes the ever loving hell out of it and publishes it.  I believe that most people will enjoy this game. I have never enjoyed Football, Cars or highly competitive games and yet, when the three are combined in this mental moshpit of a video game, it just works.  Is it worth £15? It might not seem that way at face value but if you trust the game enough to buy it, you'll recieve an incredibly rewarding and hilariously satisfying game that you can just keep coming back to.  It's not without it's negatives. The AI, although challenging to entry level players, becomes hilariously inept after a good 50 or so hours in and I do disapprove of the crate and key system, but my hundreds of hours in game should prove that it hasn't really bothered me enough to make me stop playing.  Rocket League is fast paced, addictive, and definitely worth picking up, ESPECIALLY on sale!

I would seriously recommend playing even if you arent a fan of soccer/football, because its just addictting as hell and a large community base thoroughly enjoy it 5/5 Toasster Waffles

Rocket League. Where to begin? This game is amazing, from the fast paced action, to amazing graphics, to the sheer amount of customisation.  Pros: - Amazing Graphics - Fast Paced Games with no room for error - Hundreds of Thousands of different customisations - Controllers Supported - Easy to get the hang of - Lots of room for improvement and learning new skills - Challenging to Master (meaning lots to play) - Very helpful tutorials and training missions - Up to 4 player split screen with controllers - The DLC are amazing and worth every cent! - Never gets boring (for me atleast)  Cons:  - No support for partying with PS4 players - Some of the community can be annoying but this will hardly affect the gameplay.  So in conclusion, Rocket League is a fantastic game and I highly reccomend it to anyone considering buying it. Rocket League, basically the result of if soccer and RC cars had a baby. A really fast paced and destructive baby. Rocket League is a physics based game of soccer, where you instead of controlling a humanoid player, instead you are controlling a car with a rocket strapped to the back where you try to hit an oversiezed ball into the opposite goal of your color. What makes this game so genius is how simple it is but at the same time it is deep enough and complex enough to master so it would qualify as an esport all on its own while sitting next to other esport titles such as league of legends, Dota 2, as well as a number of fighting titles and more. This game while outside the core game modes such as 1v1 up to the hectic 4v4, it is rather light on everything else, pretty much everything else is unlocking cosmetics such as hats for your cars, paint schemes, extra cars, and antenas; and the season mode which is basically you pick a team( each team has a different color scheme and unique color scheme). and you play against a number of bots with custom difficulty settings as well as the number of bots, sadly you cannot play season mode online but there is a hope. All in all Rocket League shines in its addictive core game mode of online teamVSteam soccer. Once you start playing you will be hooked into its addicting gameplay.

'Huh, Rocket League is on a free weekend, I guess I'll give it a try...' *1 Hour Later* 'Why didn't I play this sooner?!'  Rocket League is a very simple, but very well executed game. It's remote-controlled cars with aerial abilities and football (+ hockey, basketball and a variety of experimental areanas) combined to create an addictive multiplayer experience. On the surface it looks silly, but you really have to play it to understand what all the fuss is about; great gameplay experience with an energetic atmosphere, that requires skill to pull off some amazing goals and is even more fun with friends. Controls are solid and performance is buttery smooth to boot. Cars are customisable with new bodies, decals, paintwork, toppers (hats etc.) and antenas. New content such as game modes are added to the game for free, however you can pay a little more for some extra customisational options (though do note that these are completely aesthetic, no stat boosts of any kind).  Highly recommended to those who want to try something different. Believe me, it's worth it for hours of fun!  Edit: They're adding Steam Workshop support for custom levels, what more do you want?

I only got this game because all the reviews were great, thats one purchase made on reviews I will never regret.  Pros: - You will never be bored, game/skill progression is unrivaled by any game. There is always something new to learn! - Casaual and Competitive modes - The only thing that affects your gameplay is which car you chose, all other costomizations are visiual only - AI and singleplayer is great when you first start - Gives you a reason to live once you get addicted - Great Party and Trading systems - You will want to make friends with people you find you play best with - Awesome training modes - Custom maps to explore - Not a very hardware intense game  Cons: - You really should buy a controller if you want to get any good - You NEED a high framerate for this game, anything under 55fps will not cut it in my opinion - Once you get more experienced you will develop a dream to go to RLCS and begin to train tirelessly ignoring your homework, family, and responsibilities. You will find yourself staying up till 2:31am playing and dream of making amazing air dribbles in your studyhall as you catch up on sleep.  Tips: - Find people you play well with and try to get to know them and play with them - The youtube community is amazing. There are plenty of really helpfull tutuorials online from great players!  And...Then there's NeatMike and the rest of F2. - When chosing a car, how well you play with it is always more important than how it looks - Learn how to jump up and meet the ball asap, sticking to the ground will punish you eventually - Train, Train, Train. Pratice is the best thing you can do to help your game - Ball controll is always more impressive than lucky freestyles  Brb gonna go play, just 5 more miunites ;)

A very fast-paced and interesting game about cars playing soccer/football. Cars have many interesting features and none of the cars will be getting an advantage over eachother since the cars all go the same speed and can do the same tricks. Cars also have a wide variety of decals, paints, hats, antennas, flags, wheels, pretty much anything you could think of.   Rocket league offers a Season mode, kick off mode, training and online ranked and casual gamemodes. You can play the season and kick off modes against computer-controlled bots with a few difficulties. You can also master your playing style and all the mechanics on the training yard or with the tutorial. The Multiplayer offers a wide variety of maps and the 1v1, 2v2 3v3 and 4v4 modes. You can just create a party and play with your friends or just jump in the chaos of the random teams, Your choice!   The game has been excellent so far and with the new DLCs coming out soon i'll be expecting even more supersonic fun.  10/10 would glitch out of the map again.

This is one of my favorite games of the last decade. Satisfying gameplay and (mostly) good matchmaking. This game requires pure skill, and no in-game item will seperate/overpower you from your opponents, and team mates and vice versa. Rocket League was a game that I had zero interest in. Until I played it.   No interest in soccer games, no interest in RC cars playing it, but Rocket League is one of those games that you really don't understand until you try it.  Simple concept but very hard to master, it's extrememly fast paced and can get really intense. Playing with a friend or two is an absolute blast. There are a few different game modes, training modes, various online versus options.  A lot of customization options and unlockables for your cars.   Hands down the worst part of this game is the community that plays it. I'm sure that 90% of players are fine, but that vocal 10% that get into chat and try to troll the whole game is a really sad drawback. No, it doesn't make me angry because I can troll with the best of them, but it actually makes me a little sad that I can't honestly say something like 'really nice save,' or 'that was bad luck' to an opposing player without getting 'U MAD?' in response.  No, I'm not mad. It WAS a good save or I really do feel for you because I got a lucky shot.   Oh well. Welcome to every online gaming community ever.  Still a great game.

Super fun game. The controls are easy, the idea of the game aswell. It's pretty simple, yet the game has a high skill ceiling. Some of the fundamentals of normal Football can be applied to this game, so you are one step ahead of people if you know not to chase the ball like a crazy maniac all the time, and know how to 'kick' the ball in the right angle.  You have to put some effort into practicing how to use the rocket propeller and the game helps you with nice tutorials. The only problem I'm having with the game right now is the unbalanced matchmaking. I often get to play against people that are way more experience, so I end up being a burden to my team mates.  Also, you can costumize your car. Costumizing your car is fun, I approve it.

A very fast-paced and interesting game about cars playing soccer/football. Cars have many interesting features and none of the cars will be getting an advantage over eachother since the cars all go the same speed and can do the same tricks. Cars also have a wide variety of decals, paints, hats, antennas, flags, wheels, pretty much anything you could think of.   Rocket league offers a Season mode, kick off mode, training and online ranked and casual gamemodes. You can play the season and kick off modes against computer-controlled bots with a few difficulties. You can also master your playing style and all the mechanics on the training yard or with the tutorial. The Multiplayer offers a wide variety of maps and the 1v1, 2v2 3v3 and 4v4 modes. You can just create a party and play with your friends or just jump in the chaos of the random teams, Your choice!   The game has been excellent so far and with the new DLCs coming out soon i'll be expecting even more supersonic fun.  10/10 would glitch out of the map again.

This game is truely amazing.   At first when you start playing its hard to follow and even hit the ball. Many own-goals will pass (and still they will come at a higher level) once you figure out the controls and how to hit the ball in your advance.   Then comes the first goal. Feels amazing doesnt it? It will only get better from now. Its when you make a series of goals that you think i could do this prettier...  There where goals are, are goalies to defend the goal from happening. It might be even more important to keep goals from happening on your side than to score on the opposite site. Hitting the ball out of the goal isnt enough, the opponement might still be able to hit the ball you just cleared towards the goal, unsaveable for you... shame... The trick is to not only defend the goal, but also to defend the rebound. Its always easier to keep a tie than to work your way up from a possible defeat. This defending however might require the following:  Aerial gameplay comes in now. Not only hitting the ball in the air, but using that hit to your advance to play to a teammate or perhaps even to yourself that you will continue the aerial play. Defending aerially isnt too hard... Just try to shoot at your own goal, but way too hard and high, works for me every time.  Now that skill is aquired you can perfect those skills to your advance and work your way up the ranked ladder to eventually hit grand champion. Every win feels deserved (kind of) and every loss... well a loss. Be mindfull of your teammates, as they can be a little unpredictable.  After 1300 hours i can truely say that i enjoy the game and still look forward to play a game every single day.
in online match ping is around 300 always(reason=no Indian servers)and no option to host or create a server. but still fun to play with frnds and overall a great game.

What if you took the handling, physics, vibrancy and- fundamentally- the love of movement from Mario Kart and made a car soccer game out of it? This game. The more you play it, the more it offers in terms of fluid, dynamic movement and spatial percision. Can't recommend enough.

After first seeing this game only a few days ago on Youtube, as several of my subscribed channels posted videos this week, I knew I had to have this game (initially not wanting to spend the full price for it, but impulse has led me to where I am now). The controls for Rocket League take a little getting used to, but when you have finally mastered them it feels amazing to be launching yourself all of the field and causing the other team havoc! My favourite moments are when defending the goal, the entire opposing team charges in for a shot and you deflect and can instantly follow up with a free shot at goal yourself :D  Recommend getting a controller for easier and more fluid control, although have not tried the keyboard much to say if it is worse or not, driving with a pad is far more comfortable for me...  I found myself to really quickly adapt to the gameplay, which I think surprised a lot of the people in my early matches as the matchmaking system tries to (when it can) keep players balanced in terms of level although you will often see a team of semi-pro vs a team of at least 2 rookies. Not a lot can done about that I don't think, as your level is pretty much indiciative of your play time not your skill.

love this game, and buy 3 of 4 DLC (i'm not sure it's worth it or not).. so here is my review:  Positive:  - great physic, simple but complicated games.. - love the graphical details.. - nice customization, but i think there's should be more customization for your cars. - performance is good - community is friendly - join game is very fast almost all the time  Negative:  - sometimes the server down or having connection problem (my internet connection is fine!) mid game!! that suck, and all the player in the match having issue too!! (so this is clearly a server problem!) - Lag  - The DLC is not that awesome.. - all cars feel the same, the dev should be considering a different play style for cars, muscle cars, exotic, etc.. the cars must have a different feeling and have a different specialization and weakness.. not just cosmetic!! (BUT DONT MAKE THIS GAME PAY TO WIN) - THE LOW SOUND!! the atmosphere isn't too good when the SOUND is so LOW..!!!! FIX it.  so the + and - is complete, now the overall rating and recommendation.  - are this a good game? Yes - is this game worth to buy? Yes, but wait for the discount. - is the DLC good? depends on the taste, but i think it's not worth it to buy full price (wait for discount) - Graphic? Good, nice lighting and sharp detail. - is this game will be alive in a long time? it depends, if the dev keep this game up to date and add many new features and content everytime, it will be alive.. - how's the connection? average, sometimes bad, the server isn't top notch server. sometimes you'll be disappointed by the connection issue.   OVERALL RATING: 80/100  i enjoy played this game, buy the DLC's, and play with friends makes this game more FUN.. the issue only from Server problem, LOW SOUND, and not-too-good-DLC  i reccomend you buy it when this game on sale.. but, whatever... it's a decent game.. and very addictive.

This game combines two of the mosted hated genres, racing and sports to create a interesting and very addictive double-negative.  Rocket League is probably one of, if not the most, addictive games I have ever played. Playing soccer with CARS? WHY! Somehow it manages to captivate 100,000+ constant PC and PS4 (cross platform) players 24/7.  The servers are always fast (not the internet on my side though :P) and (most) the players are nice.  Graphics are amazing in this game, espically the camera effects and the ability to completely customize your camera settings is very nice.  Pros- VERY addictive Playable by anybody Easy to play, hard to master Never a time when nobodies matchmaking Leveling up gives a sense of progression Massive car customization Amazing detail and graphics Easy to make friends from all around the world Easy to invite friends to your party 4 Player Splitscreen  Cons- Intensive on a computer No party, between cross platform PS4 and PC  Overall, amazing game. Recommended!

Rocket League is an exciting, fast-paced Football-Driving mixup. The short matches mixed with the action packed gameplay means for countless hours of fun!  Rocket League includes vast customisation across its cars, with many different things for you to change, including tires, colours, hats and even car shapes; over 10 billion possible customisations! And if that isn’t enough, an extra 7 DLCs include another 8 cars and billions more combinations to make.  Rocket League has a small established competitive scene. With small competitions being hosted by organisations such as ESL, Rocket League’s competitive scene is beginning to grow and grow, giving the game a new level of skill and enjoyment. But the competitiveness doesn’t start from the top. With casual game modes being introduced such as “Chaos”, “Snow Day”, “Rocket Labs” and “Hoops” the game isn’t only under a competitive nature, but the game features competitive game modes and a ranking system in 1v1, 2v2 and 3v3 games where your skill will ultimately determine your rank.  The game also looks and feels brilliant. The maps and cars look pixel perfect at max settings and the game just feels generally smooth. But despite this, for me (and probably many other) the game is extremely choppy and frames are dropped at max settings, meaning that high graphics has to be sacrificed for smooth gameplay. This should be fine though if you have a high spec pc.  Altogether I think that Rocket League is an amazing game. It’s a game that can be played for 5 minutes if you have 5 minutes to spare, or played for hours on end. The enjoyment just doesn’t stop. I’ve played this game for 75 hours, and I’d gladly put in 75 more.  If you haven’t already: grab the game; grab some friends; and play!  8.5/10

Rocket League is a very addictive game, It's an original, very fast, action packed game as well. I had doubts about buying the game myself, so here are a few pros and cons that might help you decide to buy the game. If you like cars and/or balls, you should already consider buying this game.  Pros:  - Noob friendly: you can start off by facing bots and there are some tutorials that are very good in my opinion - Controller friendly (in fact I highly recommend using a controller) - Awesome party game thanks to split screen! (very underrated!) - Car custumization: there is not a whole lot you can do, but you'll never see the same car twice and it's easy to unlock new stuff - Nice gamemodes (football, basketball, icehockey and experimental arenas) - Quickchat (examples are: 'Take the shot!, Sorry! and Defending...')  Cons: - Very toxic community, it's even worse than the GTA V online community in my opinion: expect to get rammed a lot by teammates who refuse to communicate using quickchat, and enemies taunting and spamming all the time. It's not even rare to face two goalkeepers in one match (which means scoring goals is nearly impossible). Don't get me wrong, there are some nice guys and girls out there, but they sadly are very rare. - Even the most difficult bots are pretty easy to defeat once you know what you're doing. However, you can increase the difficulty (offline only) by adding extra bots to the enemy team: you can face up to 4 bots on your own. - If you don't have any friends who own this game, you may get bored pretty fast. - Cross-play is still not available: yes, you can face PS4 players, but you cannot send them friend requests/invite them to play the game  I hope you find this information useful, feel free to ask questions in the comments and I'll try to answer them :)  Have a nice day!

Easily the best football/racer game. Easy to get into, thanks to the great tutorial, but with a vicious learning curve to truly master the aerial play to become a pro. Even people who don't usually play online games will quickly grasp what it is about, and matches are short enough that it's equally suited for casual or competitive play.   I came across this game by accident, because suddenly everyone seemed to stream it on Twitch.tv while it was still in Beta. I showed it to my husband, and he got hooked, too. Then we spread the obsession to our gamer friends.   The game is optimized for controllers, but I prefer to play the PC version with mouse and keyboard; after rebinding most of the controls to my liking and experimenting with camera angles, I am doing just fine. The game controls smoothly, and I haven't experiences any lag spikes since it's out of the Beta. The graphics are gorgeous.   The only minus point I would give: There seems to be no way to play a multiplayer match in offline mode, for private LAN parties without internet access. Hopefully an offline mode will be added in the future.

EDIT: Having attempted to find a fix again, and attempted to play the game again, I've decided to change my recommendation. I can only go on my experience and, in my experience, the game is broken. Unplayable. Shame.  ORIGINAL REVIEW: Recommend with a HEAVY caveat. There's a bug that some people experience (it's out there on Google) that's been around for well over a year and doesn't seem to be getting fixed. It causes the game to act severely laggy no matter how good your connection is. When I say 'literally unplayable', I'm not mis-using the word 'literally'.  The game is super fun. I got a couple weeks play out of it before it started acting up in the aforementioned way, teleporting and rubberbanding to the point where the game is worthless. I have no connection issues, packet loss, and the game registers a decent ping. None of the fixes Google has turned up have sorted this issue.  The game is definitely worth the price *IF* it works for you. If you get this bug, however, you may as well throw your money out of a window.

It's footie, with cars.  That's pretty much it, it sounds stupid as ♥♥♥♥ as a concept for a game, because, believe me, it is. But this is hands down the best sports game on the market for a long time.  It's easy to pick up, really difficult to master, the game looks good enough, the music and sound effects are superb, the physics are in-house, but really consistent and responsive, DLC is purely cosmetic, new modes being added every now and then, Psyonix are literally one of the best devs of the moment.   If you are still doubting, give it a try during the free weekend. It's 20$ full price and totally worth it, if I knew I would've saved myself the steep cost of FIFa this year. IT'S THE PERFECT SUBSTITUTE.   Having said that, and I guess it's impossible because exclusivity rights, but PSYONIX PLS, GIFF ChampionsLeague team flags, I'd pay for that, or BPL, or Ligue1, or LaLiga, or whatever.  Go get it, you won't regret it.

The Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815) were a series of major global conflicts pitting the French Empire, led by Napoleon I, against an array of European powers formed into various coalitions. They revolutionised European armies and played out on an unprecedented scale, mainly owing to the application of modern mass conscription. The wars were a continuation of the Revolutionary Wars, which broke out in 1792 during the French Revolution. Initially, French power rose quickly as the armies of Napoleon conquered much of Europe. In his military career, Napoleon fought about 60 battles and lost seven, mostly at the end of his reign.[22] The great French dominion collapsed rapidly after the disastrous invasion of Russia in 1812. Napoleon was defeated in 1814, and sent into exile on the island of Elba; he then escaped and returned to power, only to be defeated at the Battle of Waterloo, and was exiled again, this time to Saint Helena.

I... Hate Football games Hate car games Hate football all together Hate sport  BUT...  I LOVE THIS GAME!  It is very easy to play/have fun for the everyday player but there is also a curve for you to take it to the real league. I started off playing my first 200 hours having fun and not having a care in the world. Then i got pretty good, i practiced daily, tried new things and the wow... i was 98th in the world, got into platinum (season 1 top rank).... Next season comes along, i hit the champion league (lowest of the top 3 divisions), i got up there with the big boys.. Got invited to play in the ESL tourney. I ACCEPTED! Now im a sweaty guy who takes his rank seriously..... What im saying is this game is for everyone, you can spend countless hours having a laugh and doing ♥♥♥♥all but playing around or you can take it to the next level and go into professional playing. The game really suits everyone and i would literally recommend it to anyone, Honestly guys, you cant go wrong with this buy.... Its not even that expensive really.  10/10 My favorite game!

Oh, and we have a bunch of new functions you really don't want to use.' For big displays I can recommend Windows 10, because you have basicly a good looking WIndows 7 (and some odd Windows 8 functions). But the performance of the game does not really improve. This is one of those games which look very boring. But once you try playing, you just can't stop. At the start it's a challenge to hit the ball. As you progress you learn not only to hit the ball, but also to hit it into the right direction. At this point it is very important not to only play solo duel, because at this point you have to learn to be cooperative to play any other gamemode. Later on you learn to hit the ball in the middle of the air, and then you know pretty much all there is and can try amazingly cool stunts which you can find all over youtube. Be warned though. To get to this point you will most likely need to spend about 150 hours with this game.  P.S. Mostly only playable with a controller, so either get one, or don't get this game. Keyboard controll is possible, but it's much better with controller.

If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!  - Serves 4 - 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook - 325 calories / serving - Healthy  INGREDIENTS:  - 1 orange, zested and juiced - 2tbsp soy sauce - 2tbsp sesame oil - 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli - 5cm (2in) piece root ginger - 1tbsp sunflower oil - 1 garlic clove, finely sliced - 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced - 150g Straight To Wok Noodles - 400g (13oz) chicken fillet, cut into thin slices  METHOD  Step 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.  Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.  Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.  Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the chicken and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.  Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the chicken to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.  I can't think of a proper review, so here's my favorite soup recipe:    edited:  My favorite soup: Saltibarsciai. INGREDIENTS:  For the soup:  200 g | 7 oz boiled & cooled beetroot (about 2 medium beets) 100 g | 3.5 oz cucumber (about 2 large pickling cucumbers, either fresh or pickled – see note above) 6 spring onions or 10 green onion leaves 2 hard-boiled eggs 1.5 litres | 3 pints kefir (or 500 ml | 1 pint thick natural yoghurt and 1 litre | 2 pints buttermilk) Bunch fresh dill Juice of ½ a lemon (optional) Salt to taste For the side dish:  200 g | 7 oz potatoes METHOD:  Peel the potatoes and chop into bite-sized pieces. Place in a saucepan of boiling water, add a good pinch of salt and boil until a knife can easily pierce the flesh. While the potatoes are boiling, assemble the soup. Slice the beetroot & gherkins into fine julienne. Chop the eggs into small dice. Chop the scallions or onions leaves into 1 cm (½ inch) pieces. Finely chop the dill. Pour the kefir into a large bowl or saucepan and add the chopped ingredients and half of the lemon juice, holding back some of the dill for garnish. Taste and season salt and additional lemon juice as required. Ladle the soup into bowls and sprinkle with the remaining dill. Serve the potatoes on a side plate so that they do not heat the soup.

Imagine this.  You start a game. You are the blue team.   A countdown begins from 3 and counts down to 1. The match starts.  You (me) hang back, letting your two team mates speed off to the ball leaving trails behind as you guard the goal.  The opposing team beats mine there and they hit the ball, knocking it just above my tem mate and sending it flying towards my goal.  I try saving it and miss, flying away into the air.  The ball hits the post, luckily and I cheer.  I regain my car and hit the ball, skimming it off my side as I go flying by.  One of my teammates goes past, hitting the ball forward. The ball circles around, and I turn back to get a boost which will raise me to 100%.  I spin around and go heading towards the goal and fling myself at the ball.  My team mate knocks me out of the way, mid air, and he misses the shot.  The ball flings up and I circle around to hit it again, I miss because my team mate, the same one, hits me from behind. I curse. I get blown up. I throw my controller to the ground. It breaks. My mother grounds me.  10/10 would be banged by my team mate twice again.

Rocket League is a soccer game where, rather than people running around kicking the ball, the players all drive rocket-powered cars! You can customize your car using paint, wheels, rocket trails, and even hats that you earn from winning matches. Note that all customization is purely cosmetic, and doesn't affect actual gameplay. This game is a must-have: it's easy to pick up and do a few matches every now and then and also incredibly fun, especially when you play with your friends. Even if you have no one else to play with, you can do exhibition matches or seasons with computers set to a difficulty of your choice.  Overall, I'd rate this game 9.5/10. The only thing i wish is that there were more rocket labs, they are very fun!

he server-breaking success of Psyonix’s Rocket League is a long-awaited validation of sorts for studio founder Dave Hagewood, who says his team tried to convince the world that a game best summed up as “soccer, but with rocket-powered cars” would be fun seven years ago.  “It was so difficult to communicate the pitch to publishers and platform holders back then,” he told me over Skype last week. “We’d tell them ‘Well, it’s a game about rockets and cars that can fly and jump and...they play soccer.’ And they looked at us like we were crazy!”  And to be fair, maybe they were. Psyonix eventually self-published that game as Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket-Powered Battle-Cars on PlayStation Network in late 2008 to mild acclaim, and moved on to other projects. But they never forgot about the game; in a sense, it was a Rocket League rough draft.  “It’s like we’ve been taking notes for seven years on this game,” says Hagewood, who agrees that Rocket League is basically the UE3-powered car soccer game Psyonix wanted to release back in 2008. “We didn’t want to change the core of what that original Battle-Cars game was; we just wanted to do that game again, the right way.”  How Rocket League got its start as an Unreal Tournament mod  While it’s certainly not uncommon to see a developer polish and iterate on a compelling game concept, that work typically takes place across clearly-branded sequels and spinoffs released a few years apart, at most. Rarely does a studio wait for the better part of a decade before returning to an old idea.  But the core DNA of Rocket League is even older than you think: it almost predates the founding of Psyonix itself, stretching back roughly 12 years to Hagewood’s days as an Unreal Tournament 2003 modder. Like many developers, part of his efforts to break into the industry involved modding popular games; unlike many modders, he designed something compelling enough that Epic itself came calling.  “I added vehicles to UT 2003,” says Hagewood. “Epic had done the initial support, but I made a game mode out of it. They hired me as a contractor to make that game into something for UT 2004, and that ended up becoming Onslaught.”    Psyonix co-developed the vehicle-rich Onslaught mode in Unreal Tournament 2004 with Epic Games  The objective-based Onslaught mode’s big selling point was vehicle-based combat, and it was a key contributor to the warm reception UT 2004 received from players and critics. Working on it as a contractor at Epic taught Hagewood a lot about how a real game development studio operates, and he used that knowledge (as well as his contacts at Epic) to build up Psyonix.  “We built our business on that engine,” says Hagewood. “If you needed anything in Unreal, we were the company to call. But our ultimate goal was to make our own games.”  And indeed, Psyonix has worked on a smorgasbord of games throughout its history -- putting in contract work on projects like XCOM and Mass Effect 3 as well as developing its own games, like Arc Squadron and Nosgoth. But the simply joy of making those Unreal Tournament buggies bounce and fly stuck with Hagewood long after his contract with Epic was up.    'If you have a game concept that doesn't do well, it's not necessarily true that the concept is a failure. Maybe it just needs to be done in a better way, or at a better time.'  “That was kind of my big break in the industry, and me and Ben Beckwith, who was a level designer at the time, were really having a lot of fun taking one of the cars in the expansion pack and making it like, jump and spin in the air and do tricks and stuff like that,” he recalls. “After we started doing our own thing, we were trying to figure out how to make something really cool out of that car stuff.”  They tried all the obvious options -- adding in racing modes, obstacles courses and straight up car combat arenas. Nothing really stood out, until “Someone said ‘Hey, let’s put a ball in here,’” remembers Hagewood.  “I think he was a fan of Deathball at the time. So we started playing it, and within a week, nobody was doing any work -- they were just playing this game.”  The designers at Psyonix found that the physics-based charm of bouncing and rocketing cars around an arena was best complemented by heaving a massive ball in there with them.  “The rocket booster on the cars was really originally intended to just be like, a turbo option,” says Hagewood. “But we discovered, completely by accident, that you could jump, keep bosting straight up, and literally fly across the arena. It was the kind of emergent gameplay we had to keep around, and a few weeks later people were hitting goals by just rocketing straight across the maps.”  Hagewood remembers how much fun the Psyonix team had zooming around the field and smashing into the ball so fast it would fly like a bullet across the field and into the goal, but he also credits that frenetic design with turning off a lot of people to the original Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket-Powered Battle Cars.    Psyonix's 2008 PSN game Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket-Powered Battle Cars  “The original was too hardcore, so we slowed down the gameplay a little bit [for Rocket League],” Hagewood tells me. “And there were issues with online too, because we couldn't afford a dedicated server network back then. So if players happened to connect to someone with a laggy connection, it was a bad experience for everyone.”  Psyonix learned from the experience, and built the cross-platform (PC and PlayStation 4) multiplayer of Rocket League to rely on its tech wherever possible.  'We did a great deal of Rocket League's online services ourselves...we tried to make a lot of it independent and platform-agnostic on our server side,” says Hagewood. “From there, all we had to do was write interfaces to the various platforms so they all talked well together; by the time the data gets to the game's server network, the network doesn't care what platform anyone is on -- it just notes 'oh this person is on Steam, this person is on Sony,' and so on.”  This is intriguing for at least two reasons: first, it means that Psyonix had to figure out how to build a cross-platform multiplayer solution that played nice with the unique demands of two very different platform holders.  “The biggest problem is we can't mix friends lists or anything like that. Also, there are certain rules on Sony's platform about age restrictions and content restrictions, things like that,” says Hagewood. “We have to uphold those, and normally Sony can kind of control who on their platform can say what and they can ban people and stuff, and they don't on a cross-platform game. So we have to make sure there's nothing that can cross that barrier of liability to either side. That's been one of the biggest challenges, figuring out how to make it so players can communicate without breaking any of those rules.”  At launch, Psyonix simply sidestepped by not allowing players to communicate cross-platform -- when I spoke to Hagewood last week he claimed PlayStation 4 players could not see or hear messages from PC players in the same match and vice versa, though Psyonix was working to patch in support for cross-platform communication.  Dealing with success  But the studio has been bogged down solving the second, bigger consequence of rolling its own multiplayer solution -- trying to keep its servers online and functional in the face of unexpected player counts. While popular opinion of Rocket League remains high, Psyonix has been hustling to deal with persistent, pernicious connectivity issues following the game's launch.

Gonna have to change my review, now that I decided to retire after 270 hours.  The matchmaking doesn't reflect your actual skill, like in Dead by Daylight, you can lose if you escape and you can win if you die. That is determind throughout the game. If you play well, repair things, have a good chase, you are rewarded. That doesn't happen in here. You can be the best player in the match, score 10 goals, if you get a bad teammate that drags you down and you lose, you derank. Simple as that. Fair? No. Needs to be fixed? Yes. Have there been any changes made in the year or so? No. That is one, the main reason, why I retired from this game.  Another thing that matters is the addition of stupid maps in competetive. If Neo Tokyo is still in there, pray for not playing there.  You have basketball and hockey mode + Rocket Labs, which no one plays, and if you somehow find a game, you score 2 goals quickly and everyone will disconnect. So what is the point.  I am from middle Europe, and EU servers are lagging for me, while Middle-East doesn't. I don't get it.  There is now a trading system, but there are only 4 very rare items, and you only really want one of them, so what is the point.  Plus, to top it off, the community is even more toxic than DOTA's and CS:GO's combined, so be prepared for a bunch of people who will blame you if you play great, while they don't, and you derank.  1/5 stars for the concept, potential is there, but there need to be MAJOR changes made to get me interested again.

Whether You Prefer To Call It Soccer Or Football, I'm Not A Fan Of The Sport. However, Rocket League Seems To Make It Incredibly Enjoyable. The Game Is Easy Enough For Anyone To Quickly Learn, And Offers Many Different Combinations Of Designs For Your Vehicle That You Unlock Through Playing The Game. As Far As Gameplay Goes, The Speed Boosts And Aerial Flips Make For A Fast Paced And Competitive Version Of The Classic Sport, Hidden Behind The Fantastically Designed Graphics. This Game Is Easily Worth $20, And Makes For A Great Single Player Or Co-op Game.

This relates to football in the following way: The car is your foot. The rockets turn the car into your head. And mixing those two give you the ability to control the ball like a football player. And it works brilliantly!  At first it seems daunting. But one of the highpoints of the game is that you really feel the progress in control when you play it more. It's not hard to get into, but it's difficult to master. And the road there is rewarding! Play with friends who have mic's and you'll have a blast!

CDN 21.99$... That's a lot of money for suicidal thoughts. But seriously though, this game is like an equivalent of the wheel of misfortune. You join a game, the servers spin a wheel seeing what they'll give you. You can get the awesome prize which is a semi-decent to a nice game or the most common prize, where you play with over 100-200+ ping, Against people who are 'matched' to your skill level, you can join a game with teammates who play like they don't have limbs, or you can join a game where physics will just get turned off and all hell will break loose. Most of the time the RNG gods come in and butt♥♥♥♥ your team and give the other team free unstoppable goals. I will say I have 15.3 hours on record, however I have played a lot more on the xbox and my friends account. Overall, if you want this game badly, save the money for something else unless this game goes on sale for like CDN 8$. Also one more thing, Europeans are the superior race because they sit on top of the servers so you instantly lose pretty much if you vs Europeans.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I first came across this game due to the countless GIFs which made it out to be fun. I mean, its pushing a ball around with a car into the other goal, how hard is that? You'll be okay for the first dozen or so games, but this is one easy to learn, tough to master game. The more you play the more you realize what an idiot you are.   TL;DR; PRO: You can fly. YOU CAN FLY! WHAT?! CON: No boss battles.   Pros:  Easy to learn.   That sense of euphoria when you score.   One of the better online multiplayers as the matches are short which makes losing less frustrating than other games where you spend a lot of time on a match just to end up losing because of a misplay by you/team mate.   Rumble mode is a ton of fun especially with friends.   Theres tons of content online, tutorials, professional games etc., and the community is a great help!   Cons:  Needs better UI for figuring out which server has the best ping for you. Important especially if you're nowhere near to a dedicated server.   Perhaps a facility to view friends' games and add friends from the in-game menu.   Match making system can be broken at times. It will randomly pit rookies with veterans(and/or higher). I once played against a professional RLCS player from SA and I had just a dozen or so games under my belt. Not wins, mind you!   AQUADOME!! The fps drop is real.   10/10 would recommend.

It's soccer with cars... sounds simple enough but the gameplay is fast and exciting, performance is good, and the game looks great. Overall this game might not have tons of depth but the skill ceiling is extremely high and it's great to see a splitscreen PC game come out in 2015. I have devoted all of my freetime in the past twp days to learning this game, and it is incredibly rewarding! I can't really say much else besides just buy this game!

I originally thought it would be somewhat of a standard soccer game. But after playing online matches and getting the hang of it, it's become so much more fun than I've anticipated! The controls have somewhat of a learning curve, but after that it gets easier to handle.  My only problem is that there are still some bugs involved with the game. Online connectivity actually affects the match, with someone's connection pulling everyone on the team or even on the field down.  Overall I highly recommend this game. It's great for passive fun!  *Edit: Originally thought there was a bug regarding the decals, turns out there are only some decals that work with certain car bodies. Also I'd like to add that there is a problem with the DLC soundtrack, which despite purchasing, it is nowhere to be found.

Who knew that mixing football and nascar would result in Rocket League?  Rocket League is fun with friends, but doesn't decline when playing solo either. Although the game recommends playing with a controller, keyboard is definitely playable. Although I don't have a controller myself, after 5 or so hours of playing with KB I got used to it.  The matches are fast ( 5 minutes ) and there are enough different gamemode types to keep you playing, as well as extra car customization. Overall I would recommend this game to anybody who likes racing, football, or both. The community is friendly and matchmaking takes around 30 seconds tops because the game still has a very active playerbase.  Thanks for reading!

new update on 4/25 added basketball, and about 14 hours of input delay in all modes, unplayable until fixed as far as im concerned  Edit: been a couple months since basketball update where this all started, still having input latency issues, literally only game i have where this is a problem so its not on my end, tried different controllers, different usb ports, even tried kb/m, all to no avail. they keep coming out with all types of new maps n dlc's and everything else but heaven forbid they actually fix some of the issues with the game, done with it, you cant have a game where theres random spots of input latency as bad as this game has it. sitting here with constant <48ms ping and theres times where what im doing on the controller doesnt happen for almost a second in game, ive talked to others who play, quite a few saying that they're getting the same issue, some are fine with it, others not so much. sucks because i used to sink quite a bit of time into this game, it was fun as all hell, now i cant stand to play for more than a few minutes every few weeks or so because the input latency is so aggrovating. if they can fix that ill change the review back to positive, but not a second before that, until they do im just considering the fact that i spent money on this game a loss.  Edit #2: most major problems with input latency and other things have recently been fixed, feel like i can change my review to positive now, absolutely fun game when it works right, great time sink. glad they finally seem to have fixed whatever the issue was. can get back to playing again.

Unfortunately for Mifune, he is prone to a lot of danger. So, when he starts racing with his Mach 5 on the track...his dad fears for him  'You're just a boy! You can get killed doing this stuff! Please come back home and start racing professionally when you're older!' Speed Ra-Mifune's dad shouts.  'Okay, dad! I shall come home!'  This game takes place after Speed race-Mifune has grown up and becomes a better racer.  You hit a big soccer ball with cars with rockets that fly it's pretty dope. I give this game 4 dead Andy Kauffman's out of 5.

You play a mini-car shooting a SLOOOOOOOOOOOW beach baloon.  But i'm the only one to see it ^^   It can be pretty fun sometimes, but it's SO SLOOW, i see it almost as a management game : you prepare your move a long long time before to shoot the ball. It's a great game, but think hard before you buy if you want to play on Linux. I've had it for a while now, and multiplayer is pretty much broken. There seem to be some problems with the network code - I was in a multiplayer game with a ping of 32 just now but the whole screen was pulsing in and out, everything moving erratically. This has happened in every single game I've tried to play. It makes even seeing where the ball is impossible (to be honest, I couldn't even tell where I was half the time stuff was just moving so weirdly). I guess sync errors with the servers, but who knows.   It also crashes extremely frequently (every 1-2 games), but even though the crash reporter fires a half dozen times a day for me, they haven't patched the Linux client once as far as I can tell. It's hard to know if they're going to.  Local exhibition play is okay, but the bot AI is truly awful; a weird mix of perfect ball prediction and absolutely awful play. I've watched the bots sit on their own goal line as the ball rolls past them without making any effort to save. The number of times one bot on a team will just get lost at the far end of the pitch for no reason. Or you'll be in the middle of a dribble (of sorts) and a bot on your own side will fly over you and pass to the opposition... Or you'll be 2-1 up with 10 seconds left and your side will suddenly decide to score an own goal under no pressure. It's way too frustrating to recommend paying money to play against the AI.   Right now, you're paying full price for a game that is well below alpha quality on Linux.

Amazingly fun game. Skill ceiling is somewhere up in the clouds. Highly addicitve gameplay keeps me around day after day, but this game suffers from a horribly toxic community. If you are just a casual player that sticks to unranked matched or you play mostly with friends, I don't think there are many games I could recommend more highly than this. But, if you find yourself getting better and better and you switch over to ranked play, prepare to encounter salty, aggressive, and downright mean players on a regular basis, especially as you progress higher and higher up the ladder.  Maybe it's the nature of competitive gameplay, but as a person who has played a considerable number of hours in other competitive games in the past, this one is up high on the list of toxic communities. The playerbase of Rocket League, far more than the gameplay itself, frequently leaves me feeling upset and irritated after just a few matches. Every minor mistake is immediately met with punishing insults and taunting by your own teammates. Even though I will continue to play this game, it is because of the community that I encounter day after day that I have to say I ultimately do not recommend this game.  TLDR:  Great fun for casual play or matches with friends. But if you are looking for a competitive game to enjoy, this one has a horribly toxic community that will leave you feeling frustrated and angry more than anything else.

The game in itself is great, it looks good and the gameplay in itself is absolutely fenomenal...  And after all of this the whole game is just a big dissapointment. First of all the matchmaking will make you want to drink bleach since it dishes out mismatches every second game or finds out countless of other ways to f**k up the match before it even starts. Secondly I can say that I have played games from CoD's to League of Legends but Rocket League has the most toxic community there is for sure. There's not a single game where someone isn't screaming insults to the mic, writing trash comments in the chat or spamming the quickchat (Which by the way is the dumbest addition to ANY game, quickchat's have allways been and will allways be trash that only results in spamming and whatnot)  Then there's the whole 'physics' part which is driving me nuts... Sometimes just a light tap to another car sends them flying to another reality whereas sometimes even if you ram into someone with supersonic speeds it's like you've hit god himself, when the other car simply stops you on your tracks.. And lastly atleast in my opinion, every addition they've made after the *Battle Cars dlc has been making the game somehow worse. It's like the creators are pushing content out forcibly on gunpoint, since they seem to lack the fun and simplicity that made this game so special to me once..    So when you combine this matchmaking system with the toxic community and half-a**ed physics you're just bound to not have a good time.  As an idea, visually and atleast somewhat mechanically this game is surely a 9-10/10, but when you're actually playing and trying to enjoy the game it's is barely a 2/10. Honestly as sad as it is to say, I wouldn't buy this game again or recommend it to anyone.
